üèÜ Tournament Overview

Who can play in these tournaments?

Any player with a Fargo rating of 445 and below is welcome! You'll need to show your Fargo account and a photo ID at registration.

Who is this tournament for, and why is the Fargo cap so low?

This tournament series is designed to give lower-rated players a competitive and welcoming environment to play and improve. The Portland and Vancouver areas already offer many open and uncapped tournaments (see below), so this event is specifically for those who often find themselves outmatched in higher-level competitions. It's time to give the underdogs their own spotlight!

  • Portland Tournaments
  • Vancouver Tournaments

Note: The Shark Shooter website may show a "connection is not secure" error. You can safely continue past that warning to access tournament information.

üìè Format & Rules

What format are we playing (8, 9, 10-ball)?

We'll alternate 8 and 9 ball weekly (starting with 9-ball on June 5th). We will also be doing Ladies Night once a month (TBA).

What‚Äôs the race format?

Race lengths vary by format, the number of players, and Fargo gaps:

  • 8-Ball:
  • 8‚Äì12 players: race to 3 wins
  • 13‚Äì16 players: race to 2 wins
  • 9-Ball:
  • 8‚Äì12 players: race to 4 wins
  • 13‚Äì16 players: race to 3 wins
  • In all formats, if there‚Äôs a 75-124 Fargo point gap, the higher-rated player must win 1 extra game, and 2 extra games for 125+ Fargo point gap

What rules are we playing by?

We follow modified BCA rules, with adjustments made by the tournament director as needed. No jump shots are allowed, and players must mark their 8-ball pocket during 8-ball games.

Are Magic Racks allowed?

Magic Racks are allowed if both players agree. If not, triangle racks are the default. You must use the same style of rack for all games in that match. Both Magic Racks and triangles will be available at the tournament.

What is a lag?

A lag is when both players simultaneously shoot a ball from behind the head string (second diamond) to rebound off the opposite rail and come back as close as possible to the starting rail. The player whose ball stops closer to the starting rail (even if it bounces off the starting rail) wins the lag and may choose to break first or defer the break to their opponent. If both balls hit the same distance, lag again or flip a coin.

Where is the tournament held?

üöó Transportation

Where can I park?

There are several parking options near River:

  • On-street metered parking: Available throughout downtown Portland. Be sure to check signage for time limits and payment requirements.
  • SmartPark Garages: The city operates five public garages nearby. More information can be found on the Portland Parking Guide.
  • Private parking lots: Numerous private lots and garages are in the vicinity. It's advisable to check availability and rates in advance.

Can I get to River on the MAX Light Rail?

The two closest MAX stops are both served by the Green, Orange, and Yellow MAX lines, as well as Blue and Yellow bus lines:

  • NW 5th & Couch
  • NW 6th & Davis

Most MAX lines run from around 4am and stop service just before midnight. For more information, see MAX Line Schedules.

What other transportation options are available?

Other transportation options include Lime scooters, Uber, and Lyft, all of which are readily available in the area.
